urn:contentItem:5JJD-8HS1-JD67-1064-00000-00Fire authority to undertake planned??burn2016-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSFire authority to undertake planned??burn

SMOKE will be visible from the Ballarat region as fire management authorities undertake controlled fuel reduction burns in coming weeks.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) and Parks Victoria will carry out the Ballarat ' Shuttleworth Rd burn, north of Ballarat.

Smoke from this 16-hectare burn will be visible to Glen Park, Invermay, Nerrina, Chapel Flat, Brown Hill, Gong Gong, Ballarat North and from the Western Highway.

Forest Fire Management Regional Manager, Grampians Forests and Fire Operations Peter Kambouris urged visitors not to enter any area where a planned burn is happening.

'We have carried out planned burns in this area for a number of seasons, working closely with key stakeholders and advising the local residents over a number of years,' Mr Kambouris said.

'Planned burning is a vital part of the fuel reduction work conducted throughout the year by highly skilled fire crews from DELWP Forest Fire Management and our partners, CFA, Parks Victoria, VicForests.'

If you see smoke and want to know if it is a planned burn or a fire, you can call the Victorian Bushfire Information Line on 1800 240 667.

urn:contentItem:5S7X-CC11-F0J6-J13N-00000-00Planned burn in the Grampians2018-05-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisPlanned burn in the GrampiansAlice Rennison

A planned burn for the Grampians will be held on Monday or Tuesday next week depending on weather conditions.

The burn will cover 700 hectares at the back of Lake Bellfield and will be visible from Grampians Road, Lake Bellfield and Grampians National Park.

Due to steep terrain helicopter aerial ignition will occur and a number of Forest Fire Management Victoria crews and vehicles will be in the area.

FFMV staff will be located at the Halls Gap Visitor Information Centre on the day of the burn.

Due to changing weather conditions, the burn will take place either on Monday or Tuesday.

urn:contentItem:5RGK-H9V1-F0JP-W4CK-00000-00You Yangs walks closed2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19You Yangs walks closed

CREWS remained on scene yesterday blacking out the You Yangs fire that broke out on Tuesday and caused walkers to evacuate.

Incident controller Tony Morris, from Forest Fire Management Victoria, said the Flinders Peak and East-West walks were closed yesterday, and will be closed today. Work continued at the site last night, and crews are working hard to see the tracks reopen tomorrow, Mr Morris said.The blaze was called under control about 3.45pm Tuesday, and the fire size was just under a hectare.

urn:contentItem:5V4P-BB91-JC0X-K289-00000-00VIC:Water bombers attack Vic fire after dark2019-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Water bombers attack Vic fire after darkMELBOURNE Jan 7

  Water-bombing helicopters have spent the night dousing a large bushfire in Victoria's east.
   The Rosedale fire in Gippsland, which has burned through 11,000 hectares, flared on several southern fronts on Sunday.


   Warnings were issued to residents in the Stradbroke and Willungareas but cooler conditions eventually helped partly subdue the blaze and the alert was downgraded.
   However extensive back-burning continued throughout the night, while the suppression choppers assaulted the main firefront.
   Victoria is trialling their night-time use and staged the first such operation on Friday night.
   The fire has burned a significant amount of pine plantation.
   So far fencing has been the only private property destroyed but there are concerns for native fauna.
   At one stage on Friday, the blaze turned on about 40 firefighters in a predicted wind change and destroyed a fire truck, trailer and bulldozer belonging to Forest Fire Management.
   A review will be conducted into how the group came to be in harm's way.

urn:contentItem:5TJK-6S21-JD34-V2G6-00000-00Planned burns to be held today2018-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisPlanned burns to be held today

Planned burns will be carried out by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA in areas near Maryborough and Heathcote today.

Smoke may be visible from Maryborough, Wareek and Heathcote until Saturday.

One burn will be in the Wareek State Forest on Maryborough-Station Lane with 132 hectares set for a fuel reduction burn.

In Heathcote, the Spring Plans Nature Conservation Reserve will have a fuel reduction burn over 89 hectares new Heathcote-Hedleys Dam Track.

The burns are expected to be completed between 9am and 8pm today.

FFV advises that road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.

Access to walking tracks or areas close to the planned burns may be restricted.

You should seek medical advice if you experience symptoms related to smoke exposure.

For more information or to check other planned burns in the region visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5TJT-5W11-F0J6-J4FS-00000-00Airport changes expand capacity2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITY NEWSPg. 14Airport changes expand capacity

The $2.2 million Corryong Airport Precinct Development project has been opened.

Works began last year on a new building, runway resurfacing, taxiway extension and lighting upgrades.

The upgrades mean Forest Fire Management Victoria can relocate firefighting and suppression activities from the grass airfield at Avondale to Corryong.

Restrictions on night-time landing and inadequate infrastructure were previous barriers to the precinct being utilised to its full potential.

Northern Victoria MP Jaclyn Symes said the upgrade, funded by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Regional Jobs and Infrastructure Fund and the Towong Council, provided long-term benefit and potentially opened up tourism.

"Aircraft play a key role in bushfire response, assisting ground crews to contain fires burning on both public and private land, and I am very pleased the Andrews Labor Government have delivered for the North East again," she said.

urn:contentItem:5THH-BNG1-F0J6-J1YD-00000-00Grains Innovation Park opens doors2018-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Grains Innovation Park opens doorsJade Bate

HORSHAM'S Grains Innovation Park was a hive activity on Thursday when people flocked from around the state to celebrate the centre's 50th anniversary.

Tours of the various facilities housed at the park were held throughout the day, while a range of activities helped people celebrate the milestone. People also had the chance to take a look inside the Australian Grains Genebank which contains more than 300 million seeds from 150 countries.

Agriculture Victoria chief executive Emily Phillips helped unveil a plaque to commemorate the anniversary.

The centre's origins started in 1967 when a group of passionate Wimmera farmers decided a grains research was needed in the region. The facility - then named the Victorian Wheat Research Institute - was officially opened on November 29, 1968.

The park is now home to the Genebank, the Victorian Fisheries Authority, Regional Development Victoria, the DELWPs Forest Fire Management Victoria and Horsham Incident Control Centre.

urn:contentItem:5SBP-0VW1-JD34-V2WX-00000-00Planned burns in the Grampians2018-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Planned burns in the GrampiansAlice Rennison

Forest Fire Management Victoria is aiming to do planned burns in the Grampians over the next few months.

"We're planning on doing burns in places such as Mount William," FFMV Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said.

"Around spring time we are planning on doing township burns in Stawell and Ararat. These are critical to the town."

FFMV did planned burns around the Grampians region last week, including in Pomonal and Boronia Track.

Planned burns "are important", Mr Rudolph said.

"People can do their own burns on private property." Mr Rudolph urges people planning to do private burns to "contact the CFA if you're in doubt".

urn:contentItem:5T7D-M171-JD34-V46J-00000-00Seeking bushfire planning feedback2018-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSSeeking bushfire planning feedbackCassandra Langley

RESIDENTS in the Grampians region can provide feedback to guide in the development of bushfire management strategies.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Grampians region assistant chief fire officer Peter Kambouris said strategic bushfire management planning was a multi-agency process.

Regional Strategic Fire Management Planning Committees guide the process to support decision making about fire management, based on risk.

Mr Kambouris said the strategy aimed to reduce the risk to things people valued most.

"Teams are now seeking community feedback to ensure that the values and objectives underpinning fire management are shared by the broader community," Mr Kambouris said.

He said one focus was understanding where to target fuel management on both public and private land.

Mr Kambouris said people wanting more information, or wanting to have their say, could go to www.engage.vic.gov.au/bushfire-planning.

urn:contentItem:5TDR-WKH1-JD34-V2P4-00000-00Burning? Watch out for escape2018-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 8Burning? Watch out for escapeElspeth Kernebone

Land owners should make sure their burn-offs are regularly monitored until fully extinguished so the fire does not escape onto public land, Forest Fire Management Victoria has warned.

The past weekend saw 14 burn-offs on private land run out-of-control.

Escaped private burn-offs happen regularly, and contribute to the number of fires on public land each year.

Paul Bates district manager for FFMVic reminded people to check the CFA's guidelines for safe burn offs.

"Land owners burning off on private land need to ensure their burns are regularly monitored until fully extinguished, so the fire does not escape onto public land," he said. "We would also like to remind people to follow the campfire safety rules leading up to a hot and dry fire season."

Two recent fires in the district were caused by escaped burn offs.

urn:contentItem:5VCD-5GY1-F0J6-J4FT-00000-00Lake activities off limits as warnings remain in place2019-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Lake activities off limits as warnings remain in placeBrian Allen

Lake Bullen Merri remains off limits to the public while a blue-green algal bloom is present in the water.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning continue to test and monitor the lake, near Camperdown, for the bloom which was confirmed on November 28.

The public was advised to avoid all water contact, including swimming, fishing and boating and eating whole fish, shellfish or crustaceans from the lake. This advice remains in place.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Otway District manager David Roberts said people should avoid the affected water until the algae disperses and warning signs are removed.

"Direct contact with blue-green algae can cause allergic reactions such as skin rashes or itchiness, sore eyes ears and nose or, if swallowed, gastroenteritis, nausea or vomiting," he said.

"Anyone who comes into contact with contaminated water should immediately wash in fresh water and seek medical advice if they experience any illness.

"Water from the lake should not be used for drinking, cooking or other domestic uses."

SMOKE might be in the air at Terrick Terrick National Park this week, with two ecological burns planned.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA crews are intending to conduct a 58-hectare burn 12 kilometres south of Torrumbarry, at Roslynmead.

The authorities said the burn should be completed between 9am tomorrow and 8pm on Thursday.

Smoke might be visible in the area until Thursday.

A 30-hectare burn is also planned 34 kilometres south of Cohuna in the Terrick Terrick National Park, at Davies Block.

The burn is likely to take place from Wednesday, weather permitting.

The following is advised for people in the surrounding community:

urn:contentItem:5TSS-F2B1-F0J6-J245-00000-00Aircraft arrive for fire season2018-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Aircraft arrive for fire season

When bushfires are sighted this summer, pilots like Lochie Tremain-Hill will scramble to assist.

Two helicopters have arrived in Bendigo in preparation for the fire season and will be used by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA.

They will respond to incidents within 80 kilometres of the city.

On the way one will stop to get water, slurping up as much as 3000 litres in 35 seconds.

"We can be on the fire ground very quickly," Mr Tremain-Hill said.

There are always obstacles pilots need to negotiate as they arrive to battle blazes. Think power lines and birds.

Water drops take place quite low to the ground and pilots must negotiate smoke and rapidly changing wind conditions.

"It (a fire) can be trickling along quite gently and then we get a gust of wind and it can be right out of control in a matter of minutes," Mr Tremain-Hill said.

One helicopter carries a water tank, another carries a supervisor coordinating aerial operations.

Firies will carry out a planned controlled burn during a five-day period in the Wychitella Nature Conservation Reserve from May 22.

A traditional burn of 7ha will be carried out 8 kms east of Wychitella by Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA, weather permitting.

FFMV said that the burn should be completed between 9am on Tuesday 22 May and 8pm on Saturday May 26, with smoke visible during that time.

Smoke may be visible from Korong Vale and Borung and surrounding areas until Saturday.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

urn:contentItem:5T7D-M171-JD34-V44P-00000-00Seeking bushfire planning feedback2018-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Seeking bushfire planning feedbackCassandra Langley

RESIDENTS in the Grampians region can provide feedback to guide in the development of bushfire management strategies.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Grampians region assistant chief fire officer Peter Kambouris said strategic bushfire management planning was a multi-agency process.

Regional Strategic Fire Management Planning Committees guide the process to support decision making about fire management, based on risk.

Mr Kambouris said the strategy aimed to reduce the risk to things people valued most.

"Teams are now seeking community feedback to ensure that the values and objectives underpinning fire management are shared by the broader community," Mr Kambouris said.

He said one focus was understanding where to target fuel management on both public and private land.

Mr Kambouris said people wanting more information, or wanting to have their say, could go to www.engage.vic.gov.au/bushfire-planning.

urn:contentItem:5S28-0SJ1-F0JP-W3C3-00000-00Memorial to bravest2018-04-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Memorial to bravestSophie Smith

EMERGENCY service workers who have died protecting Victorians may be immortalised in a memorial at Treasury Gardens.

Emergency Management Victoria, in conjunction with the CFA, has put forward a plan for a $1.8"million memorial to be erected there.

Two locations, near the pond and the John F. Kennedy stone, have been suggested in a 99-page report tendered to the Future Melbourne Committee. The memorial would acknowledge those in the CFA, MFB, Ambulance Victoria, Forest Fire Management Victoria, the SES and Life Saving Victoria."The memorial is to honour the men and women of six Victorian emergency service -organisations who have died serving the community," the report read.

urn:contentItem:5T4N-0NC1-JD34-V0TV-00000-00Spring firewood pick-up starting2018-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisSpring firewood pick-up starting

Collection of firewood from designated public land will open on Saturday, with the spring season running until the end of September.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse said there would be no collection areas in River Red Gum parks this year, and reminded residents of limits.

"You may collect up to two cubic metres of firewood per person per day, and up to 16 cubic metres per household per year; this prevents households stockpiling large volumes of firewood," he said.

"Some designated firewood collection areas may not open at the beginning of the season for various reasons, including supply or accessibility due to wet conditions.

"The felling of any trees for firewood is strictly prohibited and it's also illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence."

For more information visit ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood, or to report illegal removal of firewood, call 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5THH-BNG1-F0J6-J1W2-00000-00Horsham's Grains Innovation Park opens its doors | Photos, Video2018-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisHorsham's Grains Innovation Park opens its doors | Photos, VideoJade Bate

HORSHAM'S Grains Innovation Park was a hive activity on Thursday when people flocked from around the state to celebrate the centre's 50th anniversary.

Tours of the various facilities housed at the park were held throughout the day, while a range of activities helped people celebrate the milestone.

People also had the chance to take a look inside the Australian Grains Genebank which contains more than 300 million seeds from 150 countries.

Agriculture Victoria chief executive Emily Phillips helped unveil a plaque to commemorate the anniversary.

The centre's origins started in 1967 when a group of passionate Wimmera farmers decided a grains research was needed in the region.

The facility - then named the Victorian Wheat Research Institute - was officially opened on November 29, 1968.

The park is now home to the Genebank, the Victorian Fisheries Authority, Regional Development Victoria, the DELWPs Forest Fire Management Victoria and Horsham Incident Control Centre.

urn:contentItem:5V1T-FWV1-JD34-V0J6-00000-00A person has been injured following a fire in Laharum2018-12-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisA person has been injured following a fire in LaharumJessieAnne Gartlan

A PERSON has been injured in a fire in Laharum Tuesday afternoon.

Authorities were alerted to the blaze about 1pm.

The fire covered about 80 hectares and was deemed under control by 2.58pm.

A Country Fire Authority spokeswoman said about 20 vehicles attended the scene.

District 17 operations officer Alfred Mason said an additional 24 crew from Forest Fire Management Victoria were on site to assist.

He said the vehicles on site included a bulldozer, an excavator, aircraft from Stawell and a grader.

Mr Mason said dinner was being prepared for about 90 crew still on site, with a contingency expected to stay overnight to monitor the blaze.

"Hopefully they will just be controlling it," Mr Mason said.

The blaze was sparked by a piece of support machinery used in harvesting operations, but a more specific cause has not yet been formally identified.

Police were onsite to investigate.

Mr Mason said the injured person was a family member of the farm residents, and was transported to The Alfred Hospital for burns.

Further details regarding the injured person are still emerging from Ambulance Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5V1K-THT1-JD3N-5206-00000-00Getting on right track2018-12-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Getting on right track

A NEW mountain bike skills park has been opened in the Otways. The 500m track at Forrest features obstacles and challenges aimed at preparing riders to tackle the wider trail network.

The $30,000 track is an initiative of Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV), which has noted the sharp increase in mountain bike riding over the past few years.

FFMV Otway district manager David Roberts said the park was centrally located to the Forrest township.

"We hope the addition of the skills park opens the activity up to a wider audience, particularly to support participation of children and families in the sport," he said.

"Riders will be able to practise their skills on constructed features, such as ladders and berms, as well as different trail surfaces, such as gravel and rock." The build was overseen by specialist company Trailscapes, in consultation with the Forrest Mountain Bike Club."The project took around three weeks to complete and involved creating the trail path and building structures out of rocks, timber and heaped soil," Mr Roberts said.

urn:contentItem:5V1T-FWV1-JD34-V0J8-00000-00A person has been injured following a fire in Laharum2018-12-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisA person has been injured following a fire in LaharumJessieAnne Gartlan

A PERSON has been injured in a fire in Laharum Tuesday afternoon.

Authorities were alerted to the blaze about 1pm.

The fire covered about 80 hectares and was deemed under control by 2.58pm.

A Country Fire Authority spokeswoman said about 20 vehicles attended the scene.

District 17 operations officer Alfred Mason said an additional 24 crew from Forest Fire Management Victoria were on site to assist.

He said the vehicles on site included a bulldozer, an excavator, aircraft from Stawell and a grader.

Mr Mason said dinner was being prepared for about 90 crew still on site, with a contingency expected to stay overnight to monitor the blaze.

"Hopefully they will just be controlling it," Mr Mason said.

The blaze was sparked by a piece of support machinery used in harvesting operations, but a more specific cause has not yet been formally identified.

Police were onsite to investigate.

Mr Mason said the injured person was a family member of the farm residents, and was transported to The Alfred Hospital for burns.

Further details regarding the injured person are still emerging from Ambulance Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5THH-BNG1-F0J6-J1XH-00000-00Horsham's Grains Innovation Park opens its doors | Photos, Video2018-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisPEOPLE AND PLACESPg. 20Horsham's Grains Innovation Park opens its doors | Photos, VideoJade Bate

HORSHAM'S Grains Innovation Park was a hive activity on Thursday when people flocked from around the state to celebrate the centre's 50th anniversary.

Tours of the various facilities housed at the park were held throughout the day, while a range of activities helped people celebrate the milestone.

People also had the chance to take a look inside the Australian Grains Genebank which contains more than 300 million seeds from 150 countries.

Agriculture Victoria chief executive Emily Phillips helped unveil a plaque to commemorate the anniversary.

The centre's origins started in 1967 when a group of passionate Wimmera farmers decided a grains research was needed in the region.

The facility - then named the Victorian Wheat Research Institute - was officially opened on November 29, 1968.

The park is now home to the Genebank, the Victorian Fisheries Authority, Regional Development Victoria, the DELWPs Forest Fire Management Victoria and Horsham Incident Control Centre.

urn:contentItem:5SY6-84S1-F0JP-W555-00000-00Our crews fight US fires2018-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Our crews fight US fires

FOUR Geelong and Surf Coast emergency management personnel have been deployed to the US to help firefighting efforts on the west coast.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff from Geelong, Lorne and Anglesea will take on specialist roles in the battle against fires burning in the states of California, Washington and Oregon.

Those adding their expertise to the international contingent are field liaison officer Barry James, sector commander Lachlan Davis and safety officers Aaron Van Winden and Peter Hay.

The Barwon South West team flew out yesterday as part of a 188-strong contingent of Australian and New Zealand experts providing support.

FFMVic Barwon South West assistant chief fire officer Andrew Morrow said the experienced group would work 14-day stints during the 42-day deployment."We wish them all the best on this challenging deployment, in which they'll gain valuable skills, knowledge and experience," he said.

urn:contentItem:5TG1-JC91-F0J6-J45N-00000-00Fuel reduction burned planned for bush near Inglewood2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burned planned for bush near Inglewood

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan to carry out a fuel reduction burn near Inglewood on Friday, if weather conditions permit.

The burn will be completed between 9am and 8pm in the Inglewood State Forest, two kilometres north of the township, but smoke might be visible until Monday.

Related: Fire conditions equal to some of Victoria's worst seasons

People in the area are advised to keep windows and doors closed.

Anyone who suffers possible smoke exposure symptoms should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024.

Related: Planned burns to begin in central Victoria

The burn is one of several scheduled to take place in central Victoria this week ahead of the bushfire season.

Two separate burns are planned for locations south-west of Maryborough on Friday and Saturday.

urn:contentItem:5VC0-78K1-JD34-V53Y-00000-00Wyndham residents are being ur...2019-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Wyndham residents are being ur...

Wyndham residents are being urged to be vigilant about dangerous fire behavior.

Crime Stoppers, with CFA, Victoria Police and Forest Fire Management Victoria are conducting a Reckless Fires Cost Lives campaign during the fire season.

The campaign emphasises that whether recklessly or deliberately lit, bush and grass fires have disastrous consequences.

Crime Stoppers Victoria chief executive Erika Owens urged the community to take care.

"It's up to everyone to know the fire rules for their local area, or the areas they're travelling to, and to be mindful of their own actions and the behaviour of the people around them," she said.

"We know that information from the community helps to solve crime - we see it every day at Crime Stoppers.

"So please get behind this campaign and report what you know."

Victoria Police assistant commissioner Michael Grainger reminded the Victorian public of fire dangers and serious penalties faced by offenders.

"A recklessly lit fire, such as failing to properly extinguish a campfire, is a crime that carries severe penalties," he said.

"Penalties for causing a bushfire include up to 15 years imprisonment or fines of over $36,000."

Joanna Catalno

urn:contentItem:5S6D-JYV1-JD34-V0T3-00000-00Smoky conditions ahead with 30 planned burns scheduled in the coming week2018-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisSmoky conditions ahead with 30 planned burns scheduled in the coming weekEllen Ebsary

Thirty planned burns are scheduled across the North East in the coming week as Forest Fire Management Victoria ramps up its activities to reduce bushfire risk.

FFMV Hume Region assistant chief fire officer Gill Metz said crews were taking advantaged of good conditions forecasted. "Firefighters have successfully reduced bushfire risk through planned burning for towns including Myrtleford, Yackandandah, Bright ... Granya and Eskdale," she said.

"We aim to reduce the impact of smoke on communities from planned burning, but it's important that our crews take every opportunity while conditions are right.

"We work closely with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions ... you may see and smell smoke from these planned burns, and some roads and parks may close."

urn:contentItem:5RVT-4N51-F0JP-W3VW-00000-00Memorial for fallen heroes2018-03-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Memorial for fallen heroesAlex White

A MEMORIAL for emergency service workers who lost their lives in the line of duty will be built in Treasury Gardens.

The $2.3 million project will honour fallen heroes from the CFA, SES, MFB, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Ambulance Victoria and Life Saving Victoria.

It will also include plaques from the existing CFA Firefighter Memorial at Fiskville, which pays tribute to 78 firefighters who have died, including those who lost their lives in the Black Saturday blaze.The memorial will be installed in 2019 and the Future Melbourne Committee will view concept designs as early as next month. Emergency Services Minister James -Merlino said: "The Memorial will -provide Victoria's fallen emergency services personnel with the honour, -respect and recognition they deserve."

Forest Fire Management and Parks Victoria have advised residents of a fuel-reduction burn occurring in the Grampians.

It ignited at Cassidys Gay Road on Monday at noon and will continue burning until 6pm on Tuesday.

Smoke might be visible in the Grampians at Dunkeld and on Valley Road.

Residents were advised to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering and to avoid hanging washing out if residing next to a planned burn.

urn:contentItem:5RW4-TDP1-JD34-V341-00000-00Maldon fire declared under control2018-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisMaldon fire declared under controlTom O'Callaghan

UPDATE, noon: The small grass and scrub fire has been declared under control by the CFA.

Forest Fire Management Victoria'a Jeff Wilkie said the fire started on private property and impacted public land, meaning his group was brought in to assist fire fighting efforts.

The fire spread to half a hectare in size and was now classed as contained, Mr Wilkie said.

Some units would remain on scene.

EARLIER: Three CFA tankers are on the scene of a grass and scrub fire in Maldon, with two more on the way.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning has also been called to attend.

Note, map's pin denotes location of the street near the fire, not necessarily the address.

urn:contentItem:5TR8-MV31-F0J6-J2MR-00000-00Planned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert2018-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:58ZLexisNexisPlanned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has advised community members that a planned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert will start on Thursday, weather permitting.

The 108 hectare burn will be competed between 12noon and 6pm on November 15, with an end date of Thursday, November 22 expected.

The burn objective is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires.

FFMV has advised the community that they may be affected by smoke from the planned burns and smoke may be visible from Little Desert National Park.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke. Signs may be in place to slow traffic.

Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt.
